review_title: Awesome place to work and great company culture
pros: Cloudflare hires intelligent employees who are nice and enjoy their work. It's a great place to work because everyone is invested in the mission to help create a better internet and is willing to help out with problems across the company.
cons: Would be nice to have a 401k match.
advice_to_mgmt: You can tell Cloudflare management takes pride in building out and hiring great teams which is something I value. Overall, they are very receptive to feedback.

pros: Lots of opportunities to make your own journey and a lot to learn. The company is very fast paced and I haven't been bored once since I joined. All colleagues are very smart and driven. Internet security & performance is also a very important and interesting topic.
cons: The company is growing fast and not everything is perfect.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the culture the same for as long as possible.

pros:
If you like being part of building things from scratch, taking ownership of projects yourself, helping build structure and sustainability for the long-term, this is a great place to work.
If you want to be challenged to learn about how the Internet really works, at one of the few places where everyone really needs to learn how the internet works, this is the place to be.
If you like working with people who really care, and are building an enduring company, but are not ruthless or arrogant, you will fit in here.
cons: If you like a lot of structure and a defined focus, you will be made to feel uncomfortable. We are building out structure and accountability, policies and processes, etc., but we are not entirely there yet. We need people who want to help build those controls but don't need them.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep pushing responsibility down to teams and trusting the people you hire!

pros:
While going through the recruitment process, I was concerned by a few of the postings I read on Glassdoor, specifically about the CEO, and how he engages with employees. I reached out to a good friend who works at Cloudflare, and they took the time to go through the negative reviews and share their perspective with me. That conversation helped alleviate some concerns, still, I feared that after joining things might take a turn for the worse.

My concerns went away my first week during orientation. Upon hearing the CEO speak to our onboarding cohort it became evident he's a passionate, intelligent, caring, and thoughtful leader. Throughout the week it also became clear that Cloudflare is full of equally passionate, intelligent, caring, and thoughtful individuals.

Every day I come into the office, excited for the work I'm doing, and for the people I have the privilege of doing it with. I have regular experiences (daily) which validate my decision to work here. Cloudflare is AMAZING and the people who work here are genuinely good human beings — intelligent, capable, and inspiring — and a delight to work with. I couldn't be happier!
cons: Like many fast growing companies we have our growing pains. I don't know that I've got enough information to diagnose what the biggest challenges are. Still, in the conversations I've had it's clear that people are engaged, interested in understanding where we can improve, and will to expend the energy to make things even better (and they're already pretty awesome).
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work. I'm excited to be on this journey with you!

pros: Great Company culture, nice office, great people to work with, very good product.
cons: Can't think about one right now. There is definitely a lot to learn once you are in, but I would put this as a positive aspect.

pros:
- Insanely talented team members in all departments
- Hyper focus on maintaining strong culture and work life balance
- Fascinating and challenging technical problems
- Building a better Internet is not just a slogan it’s in the company’s DNA. You can see it happening everyday with all the features / products being worked on.
cons: None I can think of
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work

review_title: Good place to start a career
pros:
- Company does well
- Good place to start your engineering career (but not in other roles)
- Women rule, but bias for others
- Good technology
cons:
- Political, toxic culture
- CEO rules by intimidation and COO is weak
- Low pay, weak benefits, meaningless equity
advice_to_mgmt: Change them

review_title: Wonderful People with an Extraordinary product
pros: The people are truly amazing and inte.lligent. Everyone works extremely hard on the daily basis, If you like hard work you will love being on the team
cons: Lunch is only one day a week
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to hire smart hardworking people

pros:
-Autonomy is encouraged.
-Team is some of the most friendly technical people I've ever met.
-The product is good; it's easy to implement and practically a requirement for the modern web.
-New feature adds are rolling out to cover complaints.
-Culture is about improving as individuals and as a company; good team structure without any corporate kool-aid or forced ideals.
-Unlimited PTO with management who actively tries to avoid burning people out.
cons:
Employees are chained to a metaphorical rocket ship. Profit growth is happening fast, new features and stats are rolled out practically by the day, and it can be difficult to keep a handle on everything that's happening. New hires on customer-facing teams are often thrown into the fray and have to learn by doing, which can lead to some bad experiences.

QA also needs some work. Engineering change pushes and mistakes create some serious pain for customers, which roll down to the teams supporting them.
advice_to_mgmt:
-Make sure all teams have access to abundant training.
-Keep updating the documentation every time something new happens and ensure it's widely shared.
-Remember to recognize when employees are working hard for a customer.

review_title: A challenging job, but an extraordinary place to work
pros: Colleagues are incredibly generous with their time and the product itself is a thing of beauty. Truly mission-oriented. While you'll never hear it described as a "social enterprise", CF dedicates a ton of pro-bono resources to protecting democratic elections, user privacy and free speech around the world.
cons: Management operations could be improved. But Managers themselves are universally-liked. No clear path for career advancement
advice_to_mgmt: Customer-facing and product need better alignment. Promotions and/or job title changes need improvement to prevent attrition

review_title: Good Product, Weak Leadership and Culture
pros: Product is something most companies need and fairly easy to use. Definitely appeals to mid-sized companies. Mission of creating a better internet resonates with techies. Office is located by ballpark close to several other well known startups and tech companies.
cons:
Senior management (and most levels of management for that matter) often makes decisions without being transparent with other managers or employees. Very politically charged environment where you have to constantly watch your back and navigate the political landscape daily. Tension between departments and within departments regularly which can be exhausting.

I would not trust my career and development here. Anyone joining should take it for what it is worth...a unicorn name on the resume, with little long term attraction...most good talent leaves the company within 2 years because of the very cheap compensation and horrible culture.

HR team is powerless and focuses on how to get PR for the company rather than solving the real day to day problems. Company likes to hire "yes" people and this includes HR.
advice_to_mgmt: Bring in new people outside the company who know what it takes to scale a company successfully from both a business and cultural standpoint. Remove any old timers that contribute more problems than value and are in over their head. Don't be penny wise, pound foolish.

pros:
Standard issue startup perks (snacks, unlimited PTO, etc.)
Unique mission
Still a lot of smart people
Amazing core product
cons:
You're a second-class citizen whose day-to-day experience will mostly depend on the maturity of your team and the capability of your manager - both vary wildly between micro- and absentee management. Even with a great team, the best employees tend to put in 2 years and leave, and only a handful stay past the 4 year mark. People are never prioritized over the increasingly unfocused mission of re-inventing the Internet.

The management layer is a dangerous mix of inexperienced and underpowered. Many are overly concerned with how they are perceived by their bosses due to the cult of personality at the very top. Many are powerless as a lot of key day-to-day decisions are still filtered through the executive team. Headcount, compensation, and even final interviews still flow through the top. So, even a solid manager requires final approval from above them for any decision that really matters.

This means many teams are understaffed and employees find themselves overworked and underpaid. Problems tend to get hidden instead of surfaced, become technical debt and just pile up until things start breaking. The company very accurately "lurches from one incident to another" as one reviewer put it, and the employees are the ones that have to clean up each and every mess.
advice_to_mgmt:
Do right by your employees today so it'll be easier to do right by your shareholders in the future.
Stop being so cheap. You aren't a startup anymore.
Empower your people. Follow your own advice and give away your legos. Question every remaining sacred cow.

pros: Great team, exciting growing company, lot of opportunity to learn and grow and move to other teams
cons: low level role, tough grind, all about your quota atainment

pros:
Engineering is world class. I don't know how Cloudflare manages at under a 1k of employees to bring together so many brilliant, creative minds.

There are a variety of teams that all have different pros and cons. You can be fluid in your role if you are a go-getter that likes making an impact. In every team, your job is what you make it and there is a ton of room to grow and reach out beyond the scope of your role or even your team.

Austin office is isolated in terms of freedom of creativity and informed risk-taking, yet integrated with the rest of the company in terms of engineering practices and company goals.
cons: The company is at a stage where certain teams are being corporatized. Process in some teams takes up more effort than deliver value, which I believe is typical at this stage in a company. Good news is, Austin office and product strategy particularly are protected from this trend.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the bar high in terms of hiring. Don't settle just to keep the numbers up. Every mediocre hire hurts the rest of us.

pros: None that I can think of.
cons:
It was a very disappointing experience that I hope it will never be repeated ever again in my career. I have been promised a senior SRE job to find out that SRE at Cloudflare actually means watching some screens and when it blinks, click a button to open a page, from where you copy a set of instructions to paste them into your terminal.
Not only that the job descriptions are highly misleading, but it's certainly not a good place if you want to grow. Other than a theoretical description thrown on a piece of paper, there are very, very few genuine senior positions.

The culture is equally bad, everyone is afraid of the CEO, which, also shows it frequently in public, is a very narcissist person. He's also the one that decides your salary, and usually the offer he makes you is non-negociable. Get used to this, as after you join, this is going to be the pattern: whatever he says, you only have to say "yes", or you can be fired if you disagree!
Generally speaking, the higher ups have an obvious lack of previous experience in terms of management, and they understand management as a form of kingdom, they being the ones giving orders and the rest have to execute. After arguing a few times with a manager, when they run out of arguments for his terrible idea (which everyone disagreed with), he shouted: "just do it as I said".
Not to mention that there's no such thing as equality, definitely not an equal chance employer: if you kiss the right place you're privileged (and the whitelist is pretty short), otherwise they know how to make it a cold place for you.

You cannot attend a conference or a training to help you develop your skills, unless you speak. This is understandable up to an extent, but engineers typically have a strong desire to learn and expand their skill set. They don't offer anything in this direction.
The list of benefits is incredibly short and poor, rather offensive.

Leaving, was the best decisions in my career. I left shortly after I joined, being unhappy that there was a huge mismatch between what I've been promised and what I've actually been offered. At the interviews they make it looks like "hey we're all friends here" to find out how much decoupled are the teams, in reality.

The bottom line is: they don't need creative engineers, but robots that only execute orders and don't argue or have opinions / ideas.
advice_to_mgmt: Bring and keep more people with experience. Having the large amount of tech debt you have and understaffed teams, it's can't lead anywhere good.

pros: Solid product traction with mid-sized and small companies. Company has a good office location by ballpark and generally nice office space. Developers generally like Cloudflare's brand.
cons: No real culture and top leaders at company often lead by fear and public shaming of employees. Previous reviews of CEO are spot on. Engineers and sales are constantly overlooked and not appreciated. Compensation is below market, especially equity. Employee churn is a real issue here. A lot of top talent has left over the years and the trend is continuing even after hiring some HR folks.
advice_to_mgmt: Invest in and recognize people. Build a culture in the company so that employees are more engaged. Replace a lot of the old guard in management positions so that the company can get out of its own way and move on to the next phase.

review_title: A great place to do your best work!
pros:
- Working with the best, brightest, and humble people.
- Open culture and high-growth mean tons of opportunities for everyone.
- Doing a ton of good in the world by making the Internet safe.
- Unbelievably supportive leadership team.
cons: Tons to do but even more important to manage your work and life.
advice_to_mgmt: Thank you for staying focused in building a great company and culture.

pros:
I love working at Cloudflare. A tech company with a soul and employees who are super committed to the mission. The work is great and interesting. Such smart people. The leadership really puts their values in to action. Social good projects like Project Galileo and Athenian Project make me feel super proud to work here.

We are growing and leadership always works to make sure folks have career opportunities and pathways.
cons: As the company grows things change and change can be hard. I think they are approaching this growth in a super thoughtful and strategic way but there are always growing pains.

pros:
Unlimited PTO

Decent health benefits

Free snacks

Catered lunch on Wednesdays

Fantastic Marketing & Sales departments

Close to Caltrain and close to the London eye ( this is probably a con for those who actually live in London)
cons:
Narcissism in all levels of the company.

People intentionally sabotage and distract meetings to get things done their way.

Little empathy and team spirit.

Not a diverse workforce.

Internal communication frequently contains aggressive language and profanities.

Blog post driven development.

Technical debt is thrown over the fence to SRE without any consideration given to it’s reliability.

Little is transparent about the company. Engineering initiatives, financials, stock, business direction, technical decisions, etc, they’re all guarded.

No career progression for individual contributors.

Decisions are made near the top of the stack.

The only way to get something done is to not follow the processes. If a decision is made at Individual Contributor level it is hidden from the rest of the company until it's too late to discuss it.

Micromanagement is common.

Standard for hiring is really low because of the talent retention issues.

Compensation is low.

Engineering in London and Engineering in San Francisco feel like different companies.

Technical discussions are "wars of attrition" where the author and reviewer wear down each others motivation to keep making comments or replying to emails.

Very little collaboration between engineering teams. Most meetings are adversarial, shouting isn't uncommon.

Despite what a recruiter might tell you the company is not engineering driven in the slightest, the product is fairly technical but it's not driven by engineers. Everything is driven by blog.cloudflare.com

The company lurches from one incident to another, never really putting any effort into learning from past mistakes.
advice_to_mgmt:
Don't take the bus factor too literally, your people are valuable, treat them like they mean something.

Seek out data when making decisions, put real effort into avoiding confirmation bias.

Actually spend time and efforts improving your culture, hold those responsible for the toxicity accountable.

Let all of the engineering managers you promoted to keep from quitting go. Hire some managers with real experience growing a company.

Put real effort into engineering career progression and rewarding peoples achievements.

review_title: I wouldn't reccomend if you enjoy any type of support
pros: Close to transit, nice offices
cons: Incompetent middle managers, back biting co-workers, no clear direction
advice_to_mgmt: Not much. If they wouldn’t listen before it’s unlikely they will now.

pros: Working with fun, smart and dedicated people who enjoy coming to work everyday.
cons: Less of a household name, technical product to sell.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to listen to your employees, they set the tone for current and future employees.

review_title: Great place to start a career
pros: Fun/casual environment, people are nice and exceptionally intelligent, exciting place to be with rapid growth, cool products, great office location, more developed than a startup but still a startup culture.
cons: Some processes haven't quite been fleshed out yet so there can be some confusion at times, large/well-resourced competitors.

pros:
* Chance to work as part of a smart, motivated team without having to move out of Austin
* No jerks - team members are encouraging and happy to answer questions
* Cloudflare builds things that genuinely impact the internet at scale
* Austin office works on hard product and engineering problems; it's not just a satellite location
* Onboarding is comprehensive and done in San Francisco, which gives you an opportunity to meet teams in other offices
cons: * The organization is moving so fast to new challenges that it can be difficult to keep up

review_title: Brilliant engineers, worst leadership in the Bay Area
pros: The brightest engineers, full stop.
cons:
The CEO is a petty narcissist, that freaks out whenever there is an incident, and shows zero trust in his team. It’s been a known problem for years. No one does anything about it, because they are afraid of him, which is strange, because he’s not a particularly charismatic or intimidating person.

Leadership openly asks managers to write positive Glassdoor reviews, and responds to negative reviews by suggesting employees take it up with their manager. Unfortunately, there is a culture of managers not listening to employees, so nothing changes.

CEO is obsessed with creating an “office culture”, but can’t seem to describe to anyone what that means.

Leadership loves to toss around the “seat on the rocket ship” analogy, but blatantly ignores the fact that rocket ship level engineering requires rigor, deliberation, transparency, and often, moving slower to make sure the right engineering is being done.

The company lurches from one incident to another, never really learning from mistakes, yet is obsessed with growing quickly.

Disaster in the making, and the best employees are leaving right and left.
advice_to_mgmt: If you want to grow into a real company, lose all the people that have been promoted because they’ve been at the company a long time. Get senior leaders that understand people management, and put forward a real vision for the future, and talk plainly about how each team contributes to success. Stop asking employees to write positive reviews. Listen to the negative feedback and hold the people responsible, accountable.

pros: Nice facility and good location. Short walking distance from Caltrain.
cons: Lots of incompetent people in upper management loves to belittle and overwork their employees. Lost respect for upper management. COO doesn’t do anything but complain about dirty dishes. Like seriously? Is that your only contribution? Thank god having real skills matter... just because you have an MBA doesn’t mean you know everything.
advice_to_mgmt: Please don’t work as a head of anything anywhere else.

pros: Good product, great offices in SF, unlimited PTO
cons: No work from home, micromanagement is common, CEO is deified and narcissistic.
advice_to_mgmt: Replace the CEO and allow employees to work from home occasionally.

pros: Been here for less than a year and loving it. Great place for new grads and industry professionals. Working with awesome people in a work smart environment.
cons: Not a lot of processes. If you're interested in building from the ground up, this is the place.

pros:
- Interesting product
- Unlimited PTO (whether you can take it is another matter)
- Close to Caltrain and Muni rail
cons:
Cloudflare does not have mission values or company culture that promote harmony among all employees. There is a very silo-ed and clique culture within the company and it seems that those who are early employees, hold higher level position or gained favor from the CEO, will have preferential treatments than the others.

The tone from the top seems to reflect this:
- The CEO berating engineers in the company wiki for every one to see.
- A public tweet from the management publicly making fun of a company that tried to do business with Cloudflare
- An offer was extended and rescinded without explanation (search Glassdoor for this review)

If you see search for past reviews, you will notice common theme on what many people think of the CEO (Hint: Arrogant).

People are leaving in droves and quickly replaced by other newcomers and the cycle continues, including high ranking employees.

If you go to LinkedIn, you can see how many people have left Cloudflare and begin to see the pattern.

The company may have a good product, but be aware of the "culture".
advice_to_mgmt:
Start building a more respectful cultural. Implement annual performance review and anonymous 360 feedbacks across organization. Promote those who are high performers and team player. Remove those who creates a toxic culture, no matter how good they are in their job.

For the CEO: be humble.

pros: Great product in a great space and the company is on a great trajectory. It's a fun place to work with great people.
cons: Career Development and clearly defined path to grow within the company. They preach about leaders coming from within and how existing employees are leaders of the future but that isn't the reality.

review_title: Best and Most Exciting Job I've Ever Had
pros: I'm serious about the title. First thing I like about Cloudflare is the people. The founders have done a great job about creating a good, fun and diverse culture from the beginning. The three core values we look for in employees are: Smart, Empathy, and Technical Curiosity. From a product standpoint we are rocking it and our network scale and growth is awesome. We our out-innovating all of our competitors and taking market share away from them as well as growing the market with new capabilities. The sales team is fun, we're hitting our numbers, and growing.
cons: No company is perfect, and we could always do better as well. Management could do a better job of proactively working with its team members to discuss and support individual career growth plans. We're trying to do so much so fast, that sometime we bight off more than we can chew each qtr. More stock and more often would be better.
advice_to_mgmt: Communicate upcoming changes better with first line managers before announcing changes to staff. Celebrate our successes more each quarter. Add more professional/experienced managers.

review_title: Great mission and potential if managed well
pros:
- You get a lot of responsibility and autonomy
- Great mission and high impact for a smallish company
- Good place to establish yourself as an an expert (for some roles)
- Great office in SOMA
cons:
- Lack of effort in cultivating a company culture which means people often bring their bad side to work, especially the coasters (those waiting around to cash out equity)
- Company gives out very little equity, no system in place to reward high performing employees to keep them around
advice_to_mgmt:
- Make an effort to enforce a more positive culture
- Put a compensation and performance management system in place, reward employees that do well
- Invest in good HR leaders and empower them to make changes

pros:
- The future looks very bright - phenomenal growth and pace of innovation
- Truly market-leading technology that customers love
- Smartest group of people you will ever work with
- "Don't hire a**holes" is the #1 guideline in recruiting here, and it shows
- Strong feeling of teamwork and collaboration across departments in working towards our mission of building a better internet
- Solid pay and benefits, plenty of opportunity to grow and move within the company
cons:
- All companies can be doing a better job with diversity in hiring and promotions. Cloudflare is certainly ahead of the pack but can always do better.
- Internal documentation + processes are a bit of a mess and need to grow up in alignment with the company's growth
advice_to_mgmt:
- Continue to put your employees first and open up paths for opportunity and growth internally. Let people experiment and figure out how they can contribute best.
- As we grow into this major "real company" stage, make the extra effort to maintain the culture and values that brought us this far

pros:
- Genuine partnership between engineering and product
- Working on important stuff - the INTERNET! No uber for cats here...
- Super technical. Ex-engineers will do well.
- No jerks
- Rocketship
- Visa sponsorship.
- Teams small enough to be start-uppy, but big enough to get stuff done.
cons:
- Rocketship... great opportunity, but also complexity and growth can be hard.
- No referral bonus
advice_to_mgmt:
I'm only 7 weeks in, but I'm very happy with management so far. They communicate where they want to go and give us the resources to get there. They're realistic that growing at the pace we are is challenging, but that it also provides opportunity.

The founders were a key part of onboarding and continue to communicate their vision regularly and at quarterly planning.

So far so good. You've built an amazing company.

review_title: The best company I've ever worked for
pros:
* Very technical co-workers
* Fantastic healthcare benefits
* Interesting internal presentations
* There are a lot of opportunities to be challenged (not just work projects, but technical reading groups, technical presentations, etc.)
* There's a lot of work to be done
* I'm never the smartest person in the room
* I have a lot of autonomy in how I work and what I work on
cons: There are a few growing pains as Cloudflare figures out how to be a bigger company. There's a lack of cohesion in product design and development (but this is being addressed).
advice_to_mgmt: It's fun to ship products and features. However, we need to take a step back sometimes and think about the broader implications of shipping before prime-time. It affects the Cloudflare brand when a product isn't polished. We need more designers that truly and holistically understand our product.

pros: Incredible place to work. My management is very supportive and has helped me grow. The company culture is excellent. I feel surrounded by impressive intelligent people.
cons: I have a long commute

pros: Mission-driven: making the internet better. Focused on diversity; inclusive culture. Respected for its unique and democratic approach.
cons: If you're not highly technical, need to come up to speed quickly

pros:
- Relatively fast hiring process
- Extremely friendly interviewing process
- Exposure to a variety of individuals during the process
- Fun and hard working-work environment
cons: - Response time after interviews (however, CF is a fast growing company)
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing!

pros: - The people are amazing and the training is very good. Is a company that it's growing and I've joined the company because I believe that they trust the potential of their employees and they want to invest in them.
cons: - Long recruitment process and sometimes they don't email you or call you.

pros:
During the interview process I was able to meet with team members from all departments within Cloudflare. This was the most positive experience in the recruitment process.

This method allowed me to gain a deep understanding of my responsibilities, insights into how I would be supported and teams work together, more importantly, see the true passion shared for Cloudflare's mission by all individuals.

At the end, the recruitment method at Cloudflare, although a bit longer than past experiences, allowed me to start with knowing a lot of my new colleagues and enhanced my enthusiasm to join the journey.
cons: Candidates should be ready for a thorough process that takes time. The reward is great but they are looking for specific individuals to join the team.
advice_to_mgmt: I would highly recommend keeping the process thorough. The talent in my new hire orientation was incredible. Cloudflare has a bright future and I am excited to be a part of the journey!

pros: The interview process was great, and all of the meetings felt more like conversations, not interviews. Meeting a broad range of people who were transparent, open, honest, and excited.
cons: Office is located far from BART.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing.

review_title: Sales can be rough if you are just starting out or need guidance, but awesome if you have passion for the product.
pros: Laid-back atmosphere with a sense of all employees working for a common goal. If you show up and work hard it will be recognized and the work is rewarding.
cons: No territories or data from sales ops regarding who should be reached out to and when. This creates a very competitive and secretive feeling in the sales team.
advice_to_mgmt: Appreciate what the sales team does for Cloudflare! Cant reach the proposed revenue goals without them.

pros: Great things to work on. Excellent engineers and fun people to work with.
cons: Senior management does not get rid of people who are problems. They are beginning to sort things out but there are a few teams that are legitimately a joke.

review_title: Growing pains and hiring bad fits
pros:
really talented colleagues
lots to do
cons:
management is often in over their heads
resource starvation leads to burn out
hires people who do not fit sometimes
advice_to_mgmt:
Be serious about recruiting and hire enough recruiters to hit your goals
Listen to the team
reward those that are carrying the load and measure them on their measurables

pros:
Cloudflare has been hands-down one the best companies for my career thus far. The company's culture is strong and understands what work needs to be done and how it should be done. There's no subterfuge! I really enjoyed the extensive and deliberate interview process that I went through. It clearly showcases Cloudflare's commitment to quality and excellence.

The management team is always accessible and thoughtful about the company's growth and people strategy, which really sets us apart.
cons: Nothing at the moment- Love this place!

review_title: I am thrilled to be part of this company
pros: The people are amazing and the work/life culture is great. I came from a very hectic, cut throat culture. So it was nice to see not all tech companies existed like that.
cons: Lots to still be built out and because of which sometimes it's a bit unorganized.

review_title: Great company overall if you're on the right team
pros: Good culture, great co-workers, certain teams have great chemistry.
cons: Lots of growing pains. Employee professional growth lacking.
advice_to_mgmt: Give engineers the tools they need to grow their career.

pros: Genius product, market leadership, bright financial future.
cons: Compensation structure makes no sense.
advice_to_mgmt: More engineers, less bureaucracy, breakfast/lunch every day.

review_title: Best group of people I have ever worked with
pros: Great management team. Very engineering driven, so prevents sales from over-selling unfinished product.
cons: None that I could name.

review_title: A perfect mix of Product, Market and People
pros:
Mission driven company with huge market potential and an excellent product.
Visionary leadership who is great at finding large untapped market opportunities.
Nicest group of people.
Fast paced and a fun place to work
cons: Under investment in certain departments such as HR have lead to less structure when it comes to performance management and career progression. Company recently hired Head of People so company is taking the right steps to overcome these challenges.

pros: Nice office, good benefits, pursuing a worthy cause
cons: People here are smart, but there's a clear divide between the old guard and the new employees. For some reason, people do not feel compelled to share Information or help onboard other employees. Everyone is focussed on what they're doing and not so much on what helps the team / bigger cause.
advice_to_mgmt: Wish them luck, but the management has to do some serious introspection if they want to outlast the competition.

pros:
Lots of really smart people that are fun to work with.
Cool office in SOMA near ballpark.
Good work/life balance.
Strong product, especially in the mid-market vertical.
cons:
Past reviews are spot on: CEO is arrogant.
Sales Leadership is disconnected from the front lines + added an unnecessary layer of management that further removes senior leadership.
Tension between sales and marketing.
Compensation and equity are well below market.
advice_to_mgmt:
Take better care of your employees - way too much turnover the past 12 months.
Improve the work environment/culture to better support professional development and career advancement. Be more transparent around business decisions; people appreciate candor and accountability. Sales Leadership should spend more time in the trenches to better understand what is actually going on in the business.

pros: People really care about the mission. Feels like we're all pulling on the same rope. Still a relatively flat structure with a lot of visibility. Beautiful office in a convenient location.
cons: Perks are good but don't blow you away. If you need all your meals provided at work this isn't the place for you. Also no 401K match.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't compromise on the values. We are likely to encounter more scrutiny and pressure regarding content that flows through the network, and making judgments on free speech starts down a very slippery slope.

pros: Smart teams, great mission, great products. I genuinely like and admire my colleagues. They are interesting, kind, funny people who also happen to be highly technical. Project Galileo, Universal SSL, Free plans for anyone all make me proud to work here.
cons: Cloudflare isn't for everyone. If you need a defined career path and are looking for robust management programs, you'll be disappointed. Lots to do, not a ton of scaffolding. Some people will love this and thrive. Others won't.
advice_to_mgmt: We have something very special. Keep focused on maintaining that. We're at our best when engineering and product take the lead. Enterprise sales matter, but building for our self-service and free customers are what get most of us excited to come to work every day.

pros: From a purely technical point of view, the work is interesting and engaging. Once upon a time it was evening meaningful. Now, most of the big problems have been solved and it's more about sustaining what has been built.
cons: As previous reviews have stated, basically "senior" management. I use that with quotes because it should imply people with experience, but this group is completely juvenile. Again, agree with a previous poster, the legal team is just odd and they take to Twitter and Facebook constantly in a way that makes you think their bonus is tied to how cool they can make them appear to the CEO. It's particularly bad lately with the election coming up as some of the in-house team are posting obviously partisan articles in ways that give the impression that it's also the company's position. If anyone should understand the rules of social media you'd think it's the attorneys...but, definitely not in this case.
advice_to_mgmt: Honestly, not sure what you can do. The IPO window is closed as all the metrics are on the decline. There is no way the public markets can get excited over this company anymore. I suppose an acquisition is the likely route, and probably will only enrich the founders at this point as the valuation is tanking. Good while it lasted!

pros:
Many smart engineers
Nice office (compared to previous office)
Decent healthcare
cons:
CEO is not a great person and is quite vocal in his lack of respect for engineers and how hard they work. He doesn't think employees need great benefits. I overhead him saying 401k was a waste of money. He uses the technical achievements of CloudFlare to draw attention away from the company's lack of any major growth and devaluation.
Promotions are non-existant.
Other cofounders really have no idea what is really going on in the company.
If you are not a few of the in crowd then you will never get anywhere in the company no mattter how smart you are.
Sales team is washed out
Pay is not great compared to other startups in SF.
Churn is much higher than reported.
advice_to_mgmt: The world of Matthew is not the real world. Drop the condescending attitude.

pros:
CloudFlare is a small company (100 engineers, another 150 in other roles) which has a big and growing impact on the Internet -- for the good. Rather than locking website operators into a single "stack" from Amazon, Microsoft, Google, or other hosting providers, CloudFlare lets websites choose how to host their site and then get top-quality network edge performance and security between their users and server infrastructure, for a price ranging from free (for millions of sites with less-demanding requirements) to about 10% of what incumbents charge for Enterprise customers.

The biggest reason to work at CloudFlare is to be a part of making the Internet a better place. In contrast to a lot of other companies, CloudFlare has an extremely permissive terms of service, valuing free speech over everything else. While there are a lot of sites on CloudFlare which people find objectionable (for varying reasons), on balance, having open access at the network layer makes the Internet a better place.

There are some big engineering problems to solve -- handling a huge volume of web requests means every other support system is also huge -- so it's a great place to get to work on hard challenges, the latest technology, and with some really smart people.

CloudFlare has both a high media profile and a large userbase, so if you tell someone you work at CloudFlare, you're likely to get a positive response.
cons:
The biggest problem with CloudFlare is a legacy of flat organizational structure. For a long time, CloudFlare clung to a "flat" organization. This was great back when the company had 25 or 50 employees, but broke down at 100-150. CloudFlare now has a top-tier VP Engineering and some solid engineering managers, but is still implementing the kind of structure a company doing as much as CloudFlare does needs to have.

For a long time, CloudFlare had below-market office environment (a cramped, poorly maintained space), but after 18 months of delays, we finally moved into an amazing dedicated building a block away. People visit and compare it favorably to any company in tech. If you want to be in San Francisco, the location is hard to beat -- a block from Giants Stadium and 2 blocks from Caltrain.

CloudFlare cash compensation is essentially at-market. Equity compensation is less than market, but the company is also on a solid financial footing and good growth trajectory (because people actually need, value, and pay for the product), so it's hard to directly compare to more "bubble-based" valuations at other companies. Benefits are decent (free snacks, but only one free meal/week). Good health insurance, no other perks.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue adding the kind of structure a great company needs. You're right to eschew process for its own sake, but chaos isn't good, either. Keep true to the values of openness and making the Internet better, and do things to bring the benefits of the product to a greater number and more varied types of customers.

pros: Company is highly visible, in large part because senior leadership goes out of their way to promote themselves personally. The overall vision and market opportunity is there, so for sure there is a possibility of a good outcome with respect to exit opportunities.
cons:
Management is really self centered. Perfect example, a lot of the "awards" they're constant going to fancy dinners to receive were actually bought and paid for via marketing dollars. They used to be really focused on a good "exit" but now I wonder with our valuation being the obvious result of a bubble if a lot of management is now on a promotion tour for their next gig.

CEO is a lawyer and sometimes I wonder if that's why we have the weirdest legal team I've ever seen. Since the CEO is obsessive about twitter everyone on that team who wants to ingratiate themselves with him uses it obsessively. Specific example they literally tweeted about a C&D we received from some rapper and the follow calls they had with their counsel. Just embarrassing to have people in those positions so giddy about getting the attention of a hip hop star that they had to rattle off a dozen tweets and facebook posts to brag about it.
advice_to_mgmt: Hire a COO who can start to run this like a real company. The opportunity is too big to let slip away, but narcissism and hubris are two things that can mess it all up for us. Also, stop hoarding equity, what we give out now is so far under market.

pros: Innovative technology which is important for a large internet group in terms of DDOS.
cons: Tough to keep in touch with the core principles which got the company started. Uncomfortable churn rate at a high engineering level.
advice_to_mgmt: listen to the people hired to do the job and consider/try constructive suggestions.

pros: super smart, highly motivated team, serious upside potential
cons: San Francisco is a very competitive marketplace for Tech companies
advice_to_mgmt: keep doing what you're doing

pros: You get to work with highly intelligent people to solve the latest problems that face the Internet. Massive amounts of data passes through the network, hackers launch complex attacks, and global politics actually effect you. It's a truly impressive place to work. And you're ultimate goal is to make the Internet a better place. That's just awesome. The office is gorgeous and loaded with great amenities to make your work experience comfortable. There's a great work/life balance, but it is still a start up.
cons: You could stand to make more money. With massive growth, it's hard to find who has the information you need, which means it can sometimes be a real challenge to complete a task. But everyone is nice enough that it's not a terribly dreadful journey.
advice_to_mgmt: Make management decisions wisely, then let them do their job. Trust the people you have, and foster more independence.

review_title: Great ideas; let management team do what they're hired to do
pros:
Cutting edge of internet--getting to be part of policy as it's made
Opportunity to work with ridiculously smart people
This company is going places
cons: Founders don't let management lead. Can tend to micromanage and leave people frustrated and powerless. Almost impossible to voice different opinions.
advice_to_mgmt: You hired talented people. Let them do their jobs--micromanaging won't scale. Be open to ideas other than your own and be willing to step back and listen. Be willing to hire people who aren't yes men or women. Acknowledge that some of the attrition happening is due to frustration about not being heard.

pros:
CloudFlare is an ambitious vision from the founding team, paired with a smart team able to deliver on it.
This combination has made a significant impact on the Internet landscape.
(all your glassdoor bytes actually transit through their product!)

The company itself is very engineering and data driven, and everyone feels personally involved in making a better Internet.
The CEO has done a tremendous job at establishing CloudFlare as a brand that is impossible to ignore.

There are still a lot of interesting technical challenges to solve.
Get a job at CloudFlare if you want to apply yourself on something big in a no-BS environment!
cons:
The organization is all flat and self-managed in a sense, that's laudable. However some people are more "in the know" and close to the execs than some others, which makes it a bit confusing.

At times it seems like the immediate story is more important than a big picture solution. But overall things seem to always move in the right direction.
advice_to_mgmt:
Pay attention to the culture to keep talents interested and happy, without having them involved in internal politics.
Make sure people from anywhere in the org still get a chance to provide creative input on solving a portion of the big-picture-problem.

Otherwise keep doing what you're doing !

review_title: The Train is Moving and it's Quite a ride.
pros:
A great place to make an impact.
The company is growing at quite a clip, and there are plenty of opportunities to stretch and develop.
The culture is flat, transparent and encouraging. It is very result-focused with flexible work schedules and locations.
Benefits are top notch and pay is competitive.

My role here fulfills the modern career needs of autonomy, mastery, and purpose.
Who doesn't want to help build a better internet?
cons: As things grow, they don't always run perfectly. If you want a smoother ride, you may be better served elsewhere.
advice_to_mgmt: Culture and rapid growth can be tricky to maintain at the same time. Management may need to let some things change and adapt to mature as a company while also maintaining our core values.

pros: CloudFlare is a high growth startup that offers their employees the ability to take part in building the company. Your opinion matters and you can influence how things get done.
cons: Anytime your scaling a company with CloudFlare's growth trajectory things can get a little chaotic. Some people need more structure and process, so a fast paced environment can be difficult.

pros: For me, the best reason to work at CloudFlare is to learn what it takes to scale a company. We have a high achievement-oriented team that is also a lot of fun.
cons: The primary challenge is lack of clarity and disparate data sources, which is to be expected in a growth company.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue proactively sharing the vision internally and aligning all groups to that vision.

review_title: The upsides don't outweigh the downsides
pros: Great mission - build a better internet - using languages like Go. The CEO is visionary - definitely has an understanding of what the market wants. The company blog is followed and often picked up by the press. The company is also growing fast.
cons: Very toxic culture - very much a cult of personality. Most of the first engineers hired have left the company. Either you are loved by the CEO or hated - there is no other way to get promotions or more money. No one on the 'executive' team has any management experience.
advice_to_mgmt: The company needs to invest more seriously in both a solid release cycle and a stable product. The development process is chaotic and is only worsening as the company hires more staff.

review_title: The best company I've worked for so far.
pros: Fun environment and great people to work with. The APAC team is rapidly expanding and we've just moved into a brand new office.
cons: None that I've noticed yet.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good works.

pros:
* The culture is great, great people, interactions with very smart people
* So many avenues once you're in to learn each and every product on offer
cons: * Nothing really... You have room to grow, speak to other departments and learn the technologies that underpin a company that sees ~10% of global internet traffic.

review_title: Pretty good company for entry level / junior
pros:
- Many smart people to work with and learn from.
- A very dynamical environment from the technical perspective, which makes it an excellent place to learn.
- Not too much micro-management.
- Startup-like benefits.
cons:
- Many strong personalities.
- Even though it's still a startup, it doesn't feel like a big team, but rather culturally divided into small groups of people that seem to compete (and sometimes dislike or even hate) each other.
- If you work from the London office, you will have to make sure that the local baron likes you (otherwise you won't be treated equally). you will surely find out quickly who's the local baron.
- Not particularly a good place for seniors (very few positions if you want to make the next step in your career).
- Things moving veeery slow on the non-technical side (for example bringing new benefits: it took years and years to finally land the much trumpeted health and pension insurance).
- Too much gossip and bad attitude towards former employees (I heard so many bad things about people that have been respected while working there, but once they left, everyone forgot about their contribution - that's not cool).
advice_to_mgmt: Be more open minded, and listen more to your employees' needs: I would have stayed longer if you would have listened to what I have to say.

pros: So much room to grow
cons: None that I can think of

pros: Good people, great company vision.
cons: Lack of sales structure and clarity.
advice_to_mgmt: Be more supportive towards the sales organisation.

pros:
Interesting technologies to work with. The fundamental product is a nice idea.

Lots of great and very clever people to work with and learn from.
cons:
Too much drive to create new products constantly because the CEO wants to IPO. There's a lot of technical debt because engineers are told to work on the new shiny and aren't given adequate time to improve or fix legacy things.

There's no formal training programs (although you are allowed to attend conferences but it's preferred that you speak if you do).

There's no compensation for being on-call.

Toxic personalities aren't dealt with at all. In general the people are great to work with but a small minority - including senior management - make it a horrible place to work. You can be publicly belittled by senior staff and even the CEO and the People team are unwilling to do anything about it. In-fighting in teams also common and not dealt with. It's common to see pull requests with dozens of comments as people argue.

The CEO has his hand in too much day-to-day activity and makes decisions that seriously impact the company, productivity and reliability of products because he had a whim. He has also turned down great candidates when all other interviewers were positive.
advice_to_mgmt:
It's all well and good saying the company doesn't condone inappropriate behaviour, but you need to actually do something about it - and that includes dealing with the CEO when he's being obnoxious.

Don't just work on new products. Evaluate priorities properly and don't ignore your engineers when they tell you about design flaws or things that will cause problems.

review_title: Cloudflare is a great place to work!
pros:
Interesting mission
Great technology - many many many different products on offer
Most people are amazing and interested in helping you and the company to progress
Super technical environment - lots of learning
Excellent life / work balance
Very high productivity on all departments

Cloudflare is a great place to work with a clear mission of making the Internet better. I really believe that most of the key people really believe in this ideal.

The company is exponentially growing and there are a lot of new products and technologies that will keep you all the time busy, interested and learning.

Most people are interesting, fun, humble and ready to help you (of course this is not 100%, but this is anywhere in life).

Finally, it is by far the most productive place I have ever worked! Lots of work, but I love it! At the same time, it does not affect in any way my personal life as teams are able to work independently from different places in the world.
cons:
Undefined processes
Some legacy tech issues
Simple things are over complicated sometimes
WFH flexibility

The pace of growth of Cloudflare in the last couple of years opened some gaps in processes. This is not a major issue but sometimes you find yourself without a clear understanding on how to deal with a challenge.

As Cloudflare is a tech company some of its internal tools are not straight forward to be configured and used.

Cloudflare is not keen on work from home (and they make it clear during the hiring process) - while I respect this approach, I think it is a privilege that should be given to proven employees.
advice_to_mgmt:
Keep investing in people! Cloudflare is not simple and each senior individual that leaves takes months to get someone else to a similar knowledge.

Don't forget to fix old stuff before releasing new products!

Focus on making life easier instead of more complicated and productivity will go up! This apply to both processes and internal tools.

review_title: Embarrassingly bad management and almost no diversity in staff
pros: Good location, free snacks, nice office when we first moved in. Not so much now we've outgrown it.
cons:
Management (or anyone) in London has no real power or direction over the US fathership despite alluding that they do, making any autonomy hard and getting stuff done harder still if your ideas deviate in any way from the US.

There is no sick pay other than SSP (£80 per week) so whatever you do, don't get sick if you do come to work here.

Most teams are split between US and UK making the time delay a pain for getting things done, and lack of strategic cross site thinking makes for easy mistakes and poor product management and development. Having split site teams also affects management effectiveness and created bad working relationships. Many people are frustrated and feel very much alone when they have most of their team on the other side of the pond.

Misogyny is rife, and untackled. Out of 140+ people in London ~7 are female after FOUR YEARS in London. US led recruitment is poor, and has zero strategy for Europe. They have no dedicated recruiting team for EMEA region.

Interviews are frequently over 10 stages long, and often last months, with little or no feedback. No outbounding on hiring so all hires tend to be white males who apply direct. Almost everyone here wants to be more inclusive but with no support from senior management on making this happen in real terms, we're stuck with being almost exclusively male.

People are very much treated as resources. There's too much work to go round those working here, and the lack of hiring prowess means it will stay that way for some time. Burnout is a thing, to the point where key technical people have started to leaving the company.

There's no product-team style set up, and product management at all in the UK is painfully understaffed and inexperienced. It's a bit like watching children's five a side where everyone just chases the ball (next release) and no one thinks about working towards a more stable strategic picture.
advice_to_mgmt:
Your people issues (or lack of people, issues) will continue to be your number one problem, until you give it the credit and thought it deserves. You may be getting away by the seat of your pants at the moment, but not only is what you're doing in hiring unethical but it's really bad for your business. Amazed you can't see this.

Really disappointing place to work after all the fluff of the interviews and their PR: they make it seem from the outside and interviews that they're ethically on the ball trying to make the world better - all they're trying to do like so many other SF tech companies is line their pockets from an IPO.

pros: Pretty relaxed working environment, low pressure.
cons:
London office is pretty disconnected from San Francisco.
High employee turnover.
Uninteresting projects.
Plenty of technical debt.
Tiring on-call rotation.
Inexperienced management.
Not many chances of career progression or salary review.

pros:
They're working on and beyond the edge of established knowledge, giving rise to some interesting problems.
The people are great to work and chat with. Different backgrounds, smart.
Active in the open source community, giving back.
cons: The recruitment process is long and arduous. There's a lot of interesting interviews, but you have to keep on the ball to keep it rolling, otherwise it will stall, and then you're stuck waiting. The HR process in general is clearly in its infantile stage, but it's clear they're actively working on improving.
advice_to_mgmt:
Keep improving the recruitment process. Right now you risk losing people simply due to attrition or plain boredom.
Be open about timelines and processes. Discuss them before you start, so the candidate has a rough idea what to expect, who they're going to talk with, how to plan.

pros:
Great people:
* Most colleagues are smart, and nice to work with
* Very varied backgrounds
* Little to no credentialism

Interesting space & scale:
* Cloudflare services a lot of today's internet
* Problems are often due to the large scale, which makes them fun

C-level is transparent (on some things):
* Board meetings are reviewed company-wide
* Financials are there for anyone to see
cons:
HR: Very immature processes

* Salary reviews don't really exist, you either get a raise after Q1 or you don't.
* No formal performance reviews (ties in with above).
* No structure around personal development. Changing teams is hard & DIY.

Benefits: Non-US employees are second class, and stock option scheme is intransparent

* UK office lagged significantly in introducing health care, and still has no pension plan.
* Total number of issued stock is treated like a secret by upper management. It seems actively discouraged to figure out what the value of your options is.
* Options scheme is tax efficient for US employees, but not for UK ones, due short excercise window after leaving.

Engineering:
* No end-to-end ownership of products: POCs are often built by one team, and then passed to someone else who has to shoulder production-readiness and maintenance.
* Not enough investment into how software is released, which is a laborious process.
advice_to_mgmt:
Offices should feel that they are treated roughly the same, and not have SF be the best in terms of benefits, etc. Show that you care about the other half of the company.

Help employees develop. They need to know what their strenghts and weaknesses are. Let them know why they got a raise, or what they should have done to get one.

Make engineers take responsibility for the software they write. Don't hand over half-finished stuff.

pros: The working environment is pleasant, colleagues are smart and interesting to work with. Opportunity to work on some great engineering challenges.
cons: Weak senior management. We've been promised a pension plan for years now and they have never materialized. Management have not made any effort to communicate their plans to introduce one.
advice_to_mgmt: The London office is treated like a second class office. Treat it better. Being a 'startup' is not a valid excuse any more.

review_title: Many things are great - not all.
pros:
Compensation. (Depending on experience.)
Travel allowance for public transport.
Free snacks, lunch once a week etc.
Depending on what market you cover - great whitespace for business to go after.
Friendly and supportive environment. You are NOT just a number.
Unlimited holidays. (see in CONS as well)
Decent product that is very relevant to today's threat landscape.
Depending on when you join/have joint you can make a real impact on this company's success and strategy.
cons:
Weak sales leadership is causing an extremely disorganised sales structure.
No sales accelerators. Commission is paid quarterly. Targets are set very high.
Very very low stock options granted.
Cloudflare is definitely an engineering driven company. This may sound alright, but wait and see when you work in sales. This is not good, really.
Unlimited holidays. (You actually take less..."guilty effect").
advice_to_mgmt:
Please have clear and concise Sales Structure. We are growing way to fast to be able to be sloppy on this end and it would start hurting really bad if awesome people would leave just because of that.
Especially if you already openly admit that you are aware of the issues.
We have all given up great jobs to join this fantastic place. Why leave a sour taste?

pros:
Free weekly lunch
Transport allowance
Good health benefits
All new hires start in San Francisco HQ, very comprehensive and useful orientation week to get to know people
cons:
Most team members in Singapore reports upward to their lead based in San Francisco
A lot of micro-managing / remote hand holding for local matters when they have no clear understanding of the issue and proposed solutions
Some level of white supremacist thinking; some level of racial stereotypes (Team members handling Singapore office affairs are of Asian descent )
advice_to_mgmt: Try not to view the local team/affairs through the eyes of one/two person

pros: It's great fun to work at Cloudflare's scale, it creates a whole world of interesting challenges to solve. Everyone is very passionate about what they do here, and there's such a wide variety of skills and backgrounds, it's a joy to work with such a diverse team.
cons: The interview process was a little haphazard.

pros: Nice office. Millions of free customers. Sense of tension rocks. Favoritism from CEO and retribution is great. Inappropriate friend relationships with exec team seem not positive for culture.
cons: This is one of the worst company environments in tech. Don't take it from me. Read a few reviews. The CEO is a deadly combo of arrogance and insecurity and the entire executive team is afraid of him. So, nothing much good happens here.
advice_to_mgmt: Get a new CEO. Define the mission and be honest with employees abort the likelihood of an equity event.

review_title: Fun place to work, doing amazing things
pros: I've never worked with so many smart and yet still sociable people. It's a great atmosphere overall. The company is generally doing great things is trying to solve a lot of difficult problems which makes work challenging and interesting.
cons: The interview process is still very problematic and turns a lot of good people off. If you can manage to get through it, it's a really great place to work.
advice_to_mgmt: Improve the hiring process - it needs a complete overhaul! Take more time to listen to your employees and don't do things just "because Matthew said so". Be careful with the team structures too - we've gone from flat to structured in a short time and there's the risk of adding too much structure.

pros:
This is very much the early days for the sales org in the company. The foundation is great for building a company that will be a once in a life-time opportunity. Smart and nice people all around. There is trust in the employees, none of that corporate BS politics that you will experience in large companies. You bring your best work and you will be successful.
Product is already very recognized and respected in the industry.
cons: Training and onboarding is not where more mature companies are. You will need to have the mindset that you have to figure things out yourself. Knowledge sharing is not where it should be, People need to be better at proactively sharing info that will make the company successful. Cramped offices, but that will improve drastically in the near future.
advice_to_mgmt: Hire faster. Much faster.
